children.subject:
This will be hard to answer since attrition could mean many different things.

1. Individual class failure rates, at least based on those taking a class for a grade can be found at schedulebuilder.berkley.edu (and on berekeleytime).

2. LS attrition in particular is hard because LS students are not admitted as a major. You could potentially track based on interest on the UC application, but I'm not sure if this data is connected with students still. (I mean, someone must be able to do the math...)

3. EECS is fairly doable since students are admitted into EECS, and I should be able to find a rough number sometime soon.

history.content: Hi all- I can get you an attrition rate for EECS. However, as, Michael points out, it difficult to get an attrition rate for L&S CS because we don't know how many are truly attempting the major. I can get you a number for EECS soon.

children.subject:
Thank you for shedding light on this important issue.  You asked about the retention in EECS so I wanted to provide some data related to retention. This is specific to the College of Engineering:

Average graduation rate at U.S. engineering schools is 56% with some schools as low as 30% (source: American Society for Engineering Education Prism, February 2012)

COE graduation rate is 87% for freshmen and 91% for transfers.

Of the 13% of freshmen who leave COE:

About half graduate from another college at Cal

About half leave Cal due to a variety of reasons 

 

Retention is not an issue in the EECS Department, however, the department recognizes the need to outreach to create a more pipeline to a more diverse pool. I would like to share our diversity and outreach websites that highlights some of the programs our department works with and lead in an effort to build a more diverse study body. 

http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Diversity/

http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/department/OutreachPrograms.shtml


http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Diversity/events-spring13.shtml

Tiffany Shaleen Reardon

Associate Director of Diversity and Achievement
EECS Department/College of Engineering

An attrition rate for EECS would be great! Can you break out down by gender and race to see the degree to which the statement "The attrition rate is highest among women and blacks" applies to Berkeley EECS? Thanks!

history.content:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/27/us/college-science-classes-failure-rates-soar-go-back-to-drawing-board.html says:
Employers and government officials have spent years complaining that there are too few people — and especially too few women and blacks — with degrees in math and science. In fact, there is no shortage of interested students, but failure rates in the beginning classes are high. At four-year colleges, 28 percent of students set out as math, engineering and science majors, but only 16 percent of bachelor’s degrees are awarded in those fields. The attrition rate is highest among women and blacks.
What is the attrition rate in EECS and L&S CS?
history.subject: What is the attrition rate in EECS and L&S?
